facts.text: Explosions occurred on 16th March 1993 just before midnight in Bow Bazar Area of Calcutta at B.B. Ganguly Street, resulting in total demolition of building at 267 and partial demolition of adjacent buildings at 266 and 268 A.

anchor.surface_text: On 16th March, 1993, just before the stroke of mid-night, people in and around B.B. Ganguly Street in the Bow Bazar Area of Calcutta heard deafening sounds emanating from thundering explosions which resulted in total demolition of a building and partial demolition of two other adjacent buildings situated at 267,266 and 268 A, B.B. Ganguly Street.

facts.text: Large number of people died due to explosions and falling debris on 16th March 1993, totaling 69 persons.

anchor.surface_text: Large number of people were trapped in and buried under the demolished buildings. It was indeed a very ghastly sight and large number of people died because of the explosions impact and or on account of the falling debris.

facts.text: First Information Report lodged at Bow Bazar Police Station under Sections 120B, 436, 302, 307, 326 IPC and Sections 3 and 5 of Explosive Substances Act, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: The first information report was lodged at Bow Bazar Police Station for alleged commission of offences punishable under Section 120B, 436, 302, 307 326 of the Indian penal Code, 1860  in short the IPC  and Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Substances Act, 1908  in short The Explosive Act .

facts.text: Commissioner of Police set up a special investigating team due to seriousness of incident.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the seriousness and gravity of the incident, the Commissioner of Police set up a special investigating team.

facts.text: Further explosion occurred on 18.3.1993 during rescue operations.

anchor.surface_text: While rescue operations were on there was further explosion on 18.3.1993.

facts.text: Pay loader picked up a gunny bag containing 22 live bombs which were later defused.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the pay loader picked up a gunny bag containing 22 live bombs. Afterwards. They were defused after examination.

facts.text: Nitro-glycerin explosives were found involved in the explosion upon examination.

anchor.surface_text: Certain materials were seized by the investigating team from the site of the occurrence and on examination, it was found that nitro-glycerin explosives were involved in the explosion.

facts.text: Pannalal Jayasora accused-appellant arrested on 29.3.1993.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the accused persons, Pannalal Jaysoara  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 299/2002  and Mohd. Gulzar  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 494/2002  were arrested on 29.3.1993 and 13.5.1993 respectively.

facts.text: Mohd. Gulzar accused-appellant arrested on 13.5.1993.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the accused persons, Pannalal Jaysoara  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 299/2002  and Mohd. Gulzar  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 494/2002  were arrested on 29.3.1993 and 13.5.1993 respectively.

facts.text: Confessional statements of Pannalal Jayasora and Mohd. Gulzar recorded by Judicial Magistrates PW81 and PW82.

anchor.surface_text: As they wanted to make their confessions, those were to be recorded before the Judicial Magistrate, accordingly, their confessional statements were recorded by the magistrates  PWs.81 and 82 .

facts.text: Commissioner of Police concluded on 11.6.1993 that TADA Act provisions applicable and accorded sanction.

anchor.surface_text: On 11.6.1993. the Commissioner of Police on examination of the case diary, statement of witnesses, reports of the experts and confessional statements came to the conclusion that provisions of Terrorist and Disruptive Activities  Prevention  Act, 1987  in short The TADA Act  were applicable. Accordingly, sanction, was accorded for prosecution of the accused persons under the said statute.

facts.text: Charge sheet submitted on 14.6.1993.

anchor.surface_text: Charge sheet was submitted on 14.6.1993.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court quashed sanction and cognizance under TADA, later set aside by Supreme Court in State of West Bengal v. Mohd. Khalid (1995 1 SCC 684).

anchor.surface_text: Accused Persons filed a writ application before the Calcutta High Court challenging the validity of the sanction and the order whereby the Designated Court took cognizance of the offences under the TADA Act. The High Court quashed the order of sanction and taking of cognizance. The matter was challenged before this Court by the prosecution. The appeal was allowed...

facts.text: Designated Court framed charges under various sections of IPC, Explosive Act, and TADA Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Designated Court framed charges under Section 120B, 436/34, 302/34, IPC, Section 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and under Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act.

facts.text: Prosecution case: Accused conspired to manufacture bombs to strike terror and affect communal harmony between Hindus and Muslims.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution, in short, is that the accused persons conspired and agreed to manufacture bombs illegally by using explosives to strike terror in the people, particularly, in the mind of the people living in Bow Bazar and its adjacent areas to adversely affect communal harmony amongst members of Hindu and Muslim communities

facts.text: Terrorist activities resulted in death of 69 persons, injuries to large number, and property damage.

anchor.surface_text: Their terrorist activities resulted in the death of 69 persons, injuries to a large number of persons and destruction and damage to properties.

facts.text: 165 witnesses examined, including star witnesses PW40 Md. Sabir Natu, PW67 Santosh Hazra, PW68 Kristin Chow Kittu.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the 165 witnesses examined, three witnesses were picked up as star witnesses to prove the conspiracy and the connected acts. They are PW. 40  Md. Sabir Natu , PW. 67  Santosh Hazra  and PW 68  Kristin Chow Kittu ,

facts.text: Designated Court convicted appellants under Section 120B IPC, Sections 3&5 Explosive Act, Sections 3(2)(i) & 3(3) TADA r/w 34 IPC; acquitted under 302/34 & 436/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: By a detailed judgment ,the Designated Court found the accused appellants guilty of offences punishable under Section 120 B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC. However, they were found not guilty of the offences in terms of Sections 302 and 436 read with Section 34 IPC.

facts.text: Sentenced to life imprisonment and fines for TADA offences, 10 years for Section 3 Explosive Act, etc.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing on the question of sentence, the accused appellants were sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for life and to pay a fine of Rs. 3000 each for commission of offences under Section 3  2   1  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC, to undergo rigorous imprisonment for five years and to pay a fine of Rs. 500 each for commission of offence under Section 3  3  of the TADA Act. They were further sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for 10 years...

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals of accused and State's appeal on acquittal under 302/34 and 436/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals filed by the accused persons deserves to be dismissed, and we so direct. Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC... The appeal filed by the State is accordingly dismissed. In the result, all the seven appeals stand dismissed.

facts.text: PW40 witnessed accused mixing ingredients and manufacturing bombs on 16.3.1993.

anchor.surface_text: PW-40 had deposed about presence of Murtaza Bhai, Gulzar Bhai, Khalid Bhai, Ukil Tenial, Khursid and Hansu while they were coming inside Satta Gali carrying two loaded gunny bags... He noticed the aforesaid persons mixing the ingredients of bombs and also manufacturing bombs.

facts.text: Accused-appellant Rashid asked Pannalal Jayasora to prepare bombs around 10-10.30 pm on 16.3.1993.

anchor.surface_text: Around 10 to 10.30 p.m. he saw Rashid, Aziz Zakrin and Lalu coming inside the Satta Gali with an old man wearing spectacles  identified as accused-appellant Panalal Jaysoara . While moving up the stairs to the upper floor, Rashid asked the old man to prepare bombs with the materials brought by him.

By a detailed judgment ,the Designated Court found the accused appellants guilty of offences punishable under Section 120 B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC. However, they were found not guilty of the offences in terms of Sections 302 and 436 read with Section 34 IPC.

By a detailed judgment ,the Designated Court found the accused appellants guilty of offences punishable under Section 120 B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC. However, they were found not guilty of the offences in terms of Sections 302 and 436 read with Section 34 IPC.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution has proved the charge of criminal conspiracy under Section 120B IPC read with other sections?

anchor.surface_text: It would be appropriate to deal with the question of conspiracy. Section 120B of IPC is the provision which provides for punishment for criminal conspiracy. Definition of criminal conspiracy given in Section 120A reads as follows 120A-When two or more persons agree to do, or cause to be done,-  1  all illegal act, or  2  an act which is number illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy

issues.text: Whether the confessional statements recorded under Section 164 CrPC are voluntary, true, and admissible against the co-accused?

anchor.surface_text: That brings us to another angle i.e. acceptability of the confession. Section 24 of the Evidence Act interdicts a confession if it appears to the Court to be the result of any inducement, threat or promise in certain conditions. The principle therein is that confession must be voluntary.

issues.text: Whether Section 10 of the Evidence Act applies to post-arrest confessional statements of co-conspirators?

anchor.surface_text: However, we find substance in the stand of learned counsel for accused-appellants that Section 10 of the Evidence Act which is an exception to the general rule while permitting the statement made by one conspirator to be admissible as against another conspirator restricts it to the statement made during the period when the agency subsisted. In State of Gujarat v. Mohd. Atik and Ors., 1998 4 SCC 351, it was held that principle is numberlonger res Integra that any statement made by an accused after his arrest,

issues.text: Whether the acts constitute terrorist acts under Sections 3(2)(i) and 3(3) of the TADA Act?

anchor.surface_text: It was urged with some amount of vehemence by the learned counsel for the appellants that numberterrorise act was involved. While dealing with an accused tried under the TADA, certain special features of the said Statute need to be focused. It is also necessary to find out the legislative intent for enacting it.

issues.text: Whether the accused are guilty under Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Substances Act?

anchor.surface_text: By a detailed judgment ,the Designated Court found the accused appellants guilty of offences punishable under Section 120 B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC. However, they were found number guilty of the offences in terms of Sections 302 and 436 read with Section 34 IPC.

issues.text: Whether the evidence of star witnesses PWs 40, 67 and 68 is reliable and establishes the prosecution case?

anchor.surface_text: First, we shall deal with the plea regarding acceptability of the evidence. It is to be seen as to what is the evidence of PWs 40, 67 and 68 and how they establish prosecution case. PW-40 had deposed about presence of Murtaza Bhai, Gulzar Bhai, Khalid Bhai, Ukil Tenial, Khursid and Hansu while they were companying inside Satta Gali carrying two loaded gunny bags.

issues.text: Whether non-examination of certain independent witnesses like Nausad and Osman is fatal to the prosecution case?

anchor.surface_text: Next comes the accused-appellants plea relating to number-examination of witnesses. Normally, the prosecutions duty is to examine all the eyewitnesses selection of whom has to be made with due care, honestly and fairly. The witnesses have to be selected with a view number to suppress any honest opinion, and due care has to be taken that in selection of witnesses, numberadverse inference is drawn against the prosecution.

issues.text: Whether the accused were exercising right of private defence, ruling out TADA applicability?

anchor.surface_text: Even if, according to them, the prosecution case is accepted in its toto, it only proves that the Muslims were trying to protect themselves in the event of a possible attack of Hindus on them. In the bomb blast which took place in Bombay a few months earlier, the police was totally ineffective and companyld number save the lives of number of Muslims and were silent onlookers.

issues.text: Whether the acquittal under Sections 302/34 and 436/34 IPC by the Designated Court is proper?

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified. Though, it was submitted by Mr. K.T.S. Tulsi that higher sentences would have been more appropriate in respect of established offences,

issues.text: Whether the Designated Court violated Section 309 CrPC by granting unnecessary adjournments?

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we may point out that the Designated Court deferred the cross examination of the witnesses for a long time. That is a feature which is being noticed in many cases. Unnecessary adjournments give a scope for a grievance that accused persons get a time to get over the witnesses. Whatever be the truth in this allegation, the fact remains that such adjournments lack the spirit of Section 309 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Star witnesses PW40, PW67, PW68 are persons with doubtful antecedents, rowdy elements under thumb of police, likely deposed falsely

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the accused appellants have submitted, inter alia, that the so- called star witnesses are persons with doubtful antecedents. They were rowdy elements who were under the thumb of police officers and the possibility of their having deposed falsely at the behest of police officers cannot be ruled out, and this is more probable.

arguments.court_reasoning: Conviction upheld under S3/5 Explosive Act r/w S34

arguments.claim: Court finds star witnesses reliable, establishes presence and bomb preparation

anchor.surface_text: First, we shall deal with the plea regarding acceptability of the evidence. It is to be seen as to what is the evidence of PWs 40, 67 and 68 and how they establish prosecution case. PW-40 had deposed about presence of Murtaza Bhai, Gulzar Bhai, Khalid Bhai, Ukil Tenial, Khursid and Hansu while they were coming inside Satta Gali carrying two loaded gunny bags.

arguments.claim: Non-examination of some witnesses not fatal, prosecution selects material ones

anchor.surface_text: Next comes the accused-appellants plea relating to non-examination of witnesses. Normally, the prosecutions duty is to examine all the eyewitnesses selection of whom has to be made with due care, honestly and fairly.

arguments.claim: Criminal conspiracy under S120B IPC proved by agreement via circumstantial evidence, no overt act always needed

anchor.surface_text: It would be appropriate to deal with the question of conspiracy. Section 120B of IPC is the provision which provides for punishment for criminal conspiracy. Definition of criminal conspiracy given in Section 120A reads as follows 120A-When two or more persons agree to do, or cause to be done,-

arguments.claim: Confessions voluntary and true per double test, S24/25/30 Evidence Act applied correctly

anchor.surface_text: That brings us to another angle i.e. acceptability of the confession. Section 24 of the Evidence Act interdicts a confession if it appears to the Court to be the result of any inducement, threat or promise in certain conditions.

arguments.claim: S10 Evidence Act inapplicable to post-arrest confessions of co-conspirators

anchor.surface_text: However, we find substance in the stand of learned counsel for accused-appellants that Section 10 of the Evidence Act which is an exception to the general rule while permitting the statement made by one conspirator to be admissible as against another conspirator restricts it to the statement made during the period when the agency subsisted.

arguments.claim: Acts constitute terrorist acts under TADA S3(2)(i)/3(3) as intent to strike terror, affect communal harmony

anchor.surface_text: It was urged with some amount of vehemence by the learned counsel for the appellants that no terrorise act was involved. While dealing with an accused tried under the TADA, certain special features of the said Statute need to be focused.

arguments.claim: Acquittal under IPC S302/34, 436/34 justified

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified.

arguments.claim: Unnecessary adjournments by Designated Court violate S309 CrPC spirit

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we may point out that the Designated Court deferred the cross examination of the witnesses for a long time. That is a feature which is being noticed in many cases. Unnecessary adjournments give a scope for a grievance that accused persons get a time to get over the witnesses.

arguments.claim: Designated Court convicted under 120B IPC, Explosive S3/5, TADA S3(2)(i)/3(3) r/w 34, acquitted 302/436/34

anchor.surface_text: By a detailed judgment ,the Designated Court found the accused appellants guilty of offences punishable under Section 120 B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and Section 3 2 1 and 3 3 of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC. However, they were found not guilty of the offences in terms of Sections 302 and 436 read with Section 34 IPC.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: me. That is a feature which is being numbericed in many cases. Unnecessary adjournments give a scope for a grievance that accused persons get a time t

holdings.text: the evidence of PWs. 40,67 and 68 even after the close scrutiny cannot be termed to be unreliable

anchor.surface_text: In the case at hand , the evidence of PWs. 40,67 and 68 even after the close scrutiny cannot be termed to be unreliable. Merely because they were the persons with nofixed avocation, the very fact that they were regular visitors to the place of occurrence described as Satta Gali makes their presence nothing but natural. Additionally, we find that relatives of PW-68 have lost lives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Close scrutiny of testimony shows natural presence in locality, relatives affected by incident, delay in statement explained by rescue priorities and chaos

holdings.text: no adverse inference can be drawn

anchor.surface_text: Above being the position, no adverse inference can be drawn. It would be appropriate to deal with the question of conspiracy. Section 120B of IPC is the provision which provides for punishment for criminal conspiracy. Definition of criminal conspiracy given in Section 120A reads as follows 120A-When two or more persons agree to do, or cause to be done,-  1  all illegal act, or  2  an act which is not illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution entitled to select material witnesses for quality evidence; non-examination of Nausad, Osman etc. does not weaken case as prosecution version established independently

holdings.text: Presence of the accused persons in and around the place of occurrence has been amply established by the evidence of PWs 40,67 and 68, as well the confessional statements of Pannalal and Gulzar

anchor.surface_text: Presence of the accused persons in and around the place of occurrence has been amply established by the evidence of PWs 40,67 and 68, as well the confessional statements of Pannalal and Gulzar. In the case at hand , the evidence of PWs. 40,67 and 68 even after the close scrutiny cannot be termed to be unreliable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement inferred from circumstantial evidence including star witnesses seeing bomb preparation, conversations, identification parades, and consistent confessional statements

holdings.text: the confessions were true and voluntary. That was not the result of any tutoring, compusion or pressurization

anchor.surface_text: The evidence clearly establishes that the confessions were true and voluntary. That was not the result of any tutoring, compusion or pressurization. As was observed by this Court in Shankaria v. State of Rajasthan,  1978  Crl. LJ. 1251, the Court is to apply double test for deciding the acceptability of a confession i.e.  i  whether the confession was perfectly voluntary and  ii  if so, whether it is true and trustworthy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrates PW81/82 followed procedure under CrPC 164; retraction after 2 years afterthought; double test of voluntariness and truth satisfied per precedents

holdings.text: Section 10 of the Evidence Act which is an exception to the general rule while permitting the statement made by one conspirator to be admissible as against another conspirator restricts it to the statement made during the period when the agency subsisted

anchor.surface_text: However, we find substance in the stand of learned counsel for accused-appellants that Section 10 of the Evidence Act which is an exception to the general rule while permitting the statement made by one conspirator to be admissible as against another conspirator restricts it to the statement made during the period when the agency subsisted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-arrest confessions not during subsistence of conspiracy agency; cites State of Gujarat v. Mohd. Atik, Mirza Akbar, theory of agency limits to while conspiracy on foot

holdings.text: plea of accused-appellants is clearly unacceptable. [...] Credible evidence proves it to be a terrorist act

anchor.surface_text: In the background of what we have said about terrorists acts  supra , plea of accused-appellants is clearly unacceptable. As was observed by this Court when earlier the matter was before it in the prosecutions appeal questioning the quashing of order of sanction and application of TADA, the preparation of bombs and possession of bombs would tantamount to terrorizing the people.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intent to strike terror inferred from bomb preparation to affect communal harmony beyond law/order; not self-defence as no apprehension of attack; preparation per se illegal

holdings.text: charges under Sections 3 and 5 of Explosive Act upheld via constructive liability under S34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: By a detailed judgment ,the Designated Court found the accused appellants guilty of offences punishable under Section 120 B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Possession with unlawful intent proved; constructive liability even if not direct explosion causers; life sentence under TADA absorbs lesser sentences

holdings.text: preparation of bombs and possession of bombs would tantamount to terrorizing the people [...] Preparation and storage of bombs are per se illegal acts

anchor.surface_text: As was observed by this Court when earlier the matter was before it in the prosecutions appeal questioning the quashing of order of sanction and application of TADA, the preparation of bombs and possession of bombs would tantamount to terrorizing the people. Credible evidence proves it to be a terrorist act. The explosion of large number of live bombs is a clear indication of conspiracy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of reasonable apprehension of Hindu attack; right of private defence does not commence pre-apprehension; bombs not shield but for terror

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution concedes; court agrees no direct evidence linking appellants to murders or arson under IPC beyond TADA/explosives

holdings.text: such adjournments lack the spirit of Section 309 of the Code

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we may point out that the Designated Court deferred the cross examination of the witnesses for a long time. That is a feature which is being noticed in many cases. Unnecessary adjournments give a scope for a grievance that accused persons get a time to get over the witnesses. Whatever be the truth in this allegation, the fact remains that such adjournments lack the spirit of Section 309 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deprecates practice of unnecessary adjournments when witnesses present; lacks spirit of expeditious trial under CrPC 309; cites prior cases

anchor.surface_text: The appeals filed by the accused persons deserves to be dismissed, and we so direct. Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified. Though, it was submitted by Mr. K.T.S. Tulsi that higher sentences would have been more appropriate in respect of established offences, we do number think it necessary to go into that question in absence of an appeal by the prosecution in that regard. The appeal filed by the State is accordingly dismissed. In the result, all the seven appeals stand dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals by accused-appellants dismissed (convictions and life sentences under Section 120B IPC, Sections 3 & 5 Explosive Substances Act, Sections 3(2)(i) & 3(3) TADA upheld); State's appeal against acquittal under Sections 302/34 & 436/34 IPC dismissed (acquittals upheld)
directions: Trial courts should examine witnesses present without unnecessary adjournments; advocates should not seek adjournments causing hardship to witnesses

Tulsi that higher sentences would have been more appropriate in respect of established offences, we do number think it necessary to go into that question in absence of an appeal by the prosecution in that regard. The appeal filed by the State is accordingly dismissed. In the result, all the seven appeals stand dismissed.
